title: Symbols: What is this @ sign called other than an 'at sign'? - Quora

response.answer_text: In addition to being called the “at” sign, the symbol is also called… “the snail” (in Italy, Wales, and Russia)“the helix” (also in Russia)“the elephant’s trunk” (in Faroese)“the monkey’s tail” (in the Netherlands)and so forth. To see a much more extensive list of names for it in a variety of languages, check out the Wikipedia entry. It lists what 60 different countries call the symbol.

Q: Symbols: What is this @ sign called other than an "at sign"? In addition to “at sign”, this symbol is sometimes called a “Commat”. That usage appears both in the HTML character codes, where it can typed in a page by using “@”, and also in the Free Dictionary. It does not appear in more traditional dictionaries, such as Merriam-Webster or the OED.
